p:
From time series data I( t) of dengue incidence in San Juan, we construct a time series of discrete-time eigenvalues (local multipliers)

t
*
. Thus, we identify segments or windows

of length T = 12 weeks and estimate a local discrete eigenvalue or multiplier, denoted
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\lambda _t^ \ast$$\end{document}

by performing a linear regression (with zero intercept) of the model I( t′ + 1) = λ * I( t′) using the data contained in each window W
t . Thus, the time series of
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\lambda _t^ \ast$$\end{document}

t
*
is generated from the moving 12-week windows, where each discrete eigenvalue
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\lambda _t^ \ast$$\end{document}

t

depends only on the values of I in each window W
t . Note that
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\lambda _t^ \ast$$\end{document}
λ
t
*
is computed from a locally varying Jacobian but is not a local Lyapunov exponent as for S-maps
21 . To define the onset of a disease outbreak dynamically, we construct a smoothed version

of the signal

using an arbitrary10-week moving average. Supplementary Fig. 1 shows that results are robust to the specific length of the moving average. A time t
c is called an outbreak onset if
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\tilde \lambda _{t_c - 1}^ \ast \, < \, 1$$\end{document}

. We note that because dengue in San Jua\n is predictably seasonal, the dynamic definition of onset coincides closely with a fixed calendar date for onset (September 1) allowing for better advance warning.
